item.description:
We tried to do this hike in August in between thunderstorms. It was actually a good thing we didn't make it to the top; too muggy and the storms rolled in just as we returned to the parking lot.

I'll bring the detailed directions Al emailed me so we can stay on the trail this time and get to the summit.

"First, don't take the trail that's right next to the parking lot. It's a 40 degree incline the whole way up. It was insane. Park in the lot,then walk along the dirt road around the lake. You'll see a sign for the nature trail. Take that up the mountain until you see a sign for the summit.

It should be about 10 maybe 15 minutes, then you'll see a sign for "Walker" take that trail for the scenic view if you'd like. Or continue up to the summit. At the summit there are a lot of towers, and some broken glass right at the top. Be careful.

You'll come out on a tar road, take a left on the road,
then a right on the first dirt road,
you'll see a little trail on your left that leads to the top, which you
should be able to see from there.

All in all it was easier than the North peak trail, unless you take the incline.
Bring bug spray, I got eaten alive, and water for everyone.

Have fun, Bella and I certainly did.
-AL"


I found these statistics about the South Mountain.

Hiking (one way, up to the summit):
Distance: 0.6 mile
Vertical: 650 feet

More Directions
item.how_to_find_us: Look for green Volvo with EPRINT plates nearest parking to the lake

group.name: Human Soles & Doggie Paws Hikers & Walkers of Manchester, NH
